courses.title: Basics of Pakistan Stock Market
courses.description: Learn how the Pakistan Stock Exchange works, what shares are, and how people invest in real Pakistani companies.

content.readingMaterial:
When you hear people say they are investing in the Pakistan Stock Exchange (PSX), it simply means they are buying small pieces of real companies. These pieces are called shares. When you buy a share of Lucky Cement or Engro, you become a small owner of that company.

The PSX has different indices like KSE-100, which shows the performance of the top 100 companies by market value. If the KSE-100 goes up, it generally means big companies in Pakistan performed well. But remember, index going up doesn’t guarantee every company is growing.

Companies list themselves on the PSX to raise money. When Engro or OGDC needs funds for expansion, instead of taking loans only, they can sell shares to investors. Investors buy shares because they expect the company to grow and the share price to increase in the future.

Share prices go up and down every day depending on company performance, news, the economy of Pakistan, political situations, interest rates, and global markets. For example, if international oil prices go up, companies like PPL and OGDC might benefit.

A common beginner mistake in Pakistan is investing blindly just because someone on Facebook or WhatsApp said “this stock will double.” Remember, investing is based on research, not rumors. Take time to learn before putting real money.
practiceQuestions: What does buying a share of a company mean?
What does the KSE-100 index represent?
Name one thing that can affect share prices in Pakistan.

quizzes.question: Which exchange is Pakistan’s main stock market?

courses.title: Understanding Indices (KSE-100, KMI-30)
courses.description: Learn what stock indices are and how they show performance of the Pakistani market.

content.readingMaterial:
An index is like a scorecard of selected companies. In Pakistan, the most famous index is KSE-100. It includes 100 top companies listed on PSX. When investors say “market upar hai,” they usually mean KSE-100 increased.

KMI-30 is another index that represents 30 Shariah-compliant companies. This is useful for investors who prefer Islamic finance rules. For example, Meezan Bank follows Islamic principles and is often part of Shariah-compliant discussions.

Indices help investors understand the overall market trend. If KSE-100 is falling for many days, it may indicate confidence is dropping due to economic or political reasons. However, some individual stocks may still perform well.

Many beginners make the mistake of assuming if the index is rising, all companies are making profit. That’s not always true. Some companies may be falling even when KSE-100 is positive.

Indices are not stocks themselves. You cannot “buy” KSE-100, but you can buy ETFs that follow an index when available. In Pakistan, ETF options are still growing and not as common as international markets.
practiceQuestions: What does an index show?
What is KMI-30 based on?
Can every stock rise when the index rises?

courses.title: Company Types & Sectors in Pakistan
courses.description: Learn different types of listed companies in PSX like banks, oil & gas, cement, fertilizer, and tech.

content.readingMaterial:
Companies on PSX are divided into sectors based on what they do. For example, Lucky Cement belongs to the cement sector, while PPL and OGDC belong to oil & gas. Engro is part of the fertilizer and chemicals space.

Sectors behave differently in different economic situations. When construction activity increases in Pakistan, cement companies like Lucky Cement may benefit. When international crude oil rises, oil companies like OGDC and PPL may show positive results.

Banking sector, such as Meezan Bank and HBL, depends heavily on interest rates and economic conditions. When the State Bank changes interest rates, banking stocks may react immediately.

Understanding sectors helps investors diversify. Instead of buying only cement shares, you can invest in multiple sectors to reduce risk. A big mistake new Pakistani investors make is buying only one hot sector because of hype.

Every sector has its own risks. For example, fertilizer companies depend on gas supply and government subsidies. So it is important to know the story behind every sector, not just the stock price.
practiceQuestions: Name two sectors in PSX.
What affects the banking sector the most?
Why is diversification important?

quizzes.question: Lucky Cement belongs to which sector?

courses.title: Basic Fundamental Analysis (Pakistan)
courses.description: Learn how to understand a company’s financial health using simple terms and Pakistani examples.

content.readingMaterial:
Fundamental analysis means checking if a company is actually performing well. This includes its profits, sales, assets, and future plans. For example, if Engro keeps increasing profits every year, that may be a positive sign.

Look at earnings (profit after expenses). If a company makes consistent earnings, it may be considered strong. But always compare with competitors. For example, compare Meezan Bank with other banks.

Dividends are payments companies give from their profit. Many Pakistani investors love dividend-paying companies like OGDC, because they receive regular income. But a high dividend alone doesn’t make a company good.

A common mistake beginners make in Pakistan is only looking at “cheap share price,” thinking Rs.20 is better than Rs.200. Price alone means nothing—performance matters. Sometimes a Rs.200 stock is much stronger than a cheap Rs.20 stock.

Fundamental analysis helps avoid gambling. Instead of randomly buying because someone said buy, you study the company. Even reading quarterly reports on PSX website is a great habit.
practiceQuestions: What does fundamental analysis check?
Do dividends guarantee a company is good?
Why is share price alone not enough?

courses.title: Common Pakistani Investor Mistakes
courses.description: Learn common mistakes people make in Pakistan while investing and how you can avoid them.

content.readingMaterial:
Many new investors in Pakistan rely on Facebook groups or WhatsApp friends for stock tips. This is risky because most of these tips have no research behind them. Always verify information from PSX or company announcements.

Another big mistake is short-term thinking. Pakistani markets can be volatile due to political news or economic decisions. Many people panic sell when the market drops and end up losing money.

Overconfidence is common. After 1 or 2 profitable trades, investors think they are experts. Then they invest heavily in risky stocks and face losses. Slow and steady learning is better.

Not diversifying is also dangerous. Buying only oil, or only banks, or only cement increases risk. Spread your investment across different sectors.

Lastly, emotional decisions are harmful. Never buy because someone says “engro chal raha hai.” Always check fundamentals. A smart Pakistani investor follows data, not hype.
practiceQuestions: Why is following random tips risky?
What happens when investors panic sell?
Why is diversification important in Pakistan?

courses.title: Risk Management for Pakistani Investors
courses.description: Learn how to control your losses, manage risk, and avoid emotional decisions in Pakistani markets.

content.readingMaterial:
Risk management simply means protecting your money from big losses. In Pakistan, markets can move suddenly due to political news, economic decisions, or sudden rupee changes. If you don’t plan your risk, you might panic and sell at the worst time.

One smart method is not investing all your money at once. For example, if you want to buy Lucky Cement worth Rs.100,000, don’t buy in one go. Buy in small parts over weeks. This reduces the effect of sudden price drops.

Stop-loss is a technique where you decide beforehand at which price you will sell your stock if it keeps falling. Example: if you buy OGDC at Rs.100, you may decide to sell if it goes below Rs.95. This prevents emotional decisions later.

Many Pakistanis invest only in one stock. This is highly risky. Instead, divide your investment between energy, banking, cement, and fertilizers. If one sector falls, others may stay stable.

Another common mistake is investing borrowed money. Never take loans for investing. Markets are unpredictable. If price falls, you not only lose money but also face loan pressure.
practiceQuestions: Why are Pakistani markets sometimes unpredictable?
What is a stop-loss?
Why should you not invest borrowed money?

courses.title: Dividends & Islamic Investments (Pakistan)
courses.description: Learn how Pakistani companies pay dividends and how Shariah-compliant investing works.

content.readingMaterial:
Many Pakistani investors love dividend-paying companies like OGDC or Hubco, because dividends give regular income. Dividend is a portion of company profit given to shareholders. However, high dividend doesn’t always mean the company is growing.

Not every company gives dividends. Some, like tech or growth companies, keep money for expansion. This is also a good sign if it is used wisely.

Islamic investments follow Shariah rules. Pakistan has many Shariah-compliant companies. KMI-30 index tracks those. Example: Meezan Bank is a well-known Islamic banking institution.

In Islamic investing, earnings must not come from interest-based income. Also debt levels must be under certain limits. If a company violates Islamic rules, it may be removed from Shariah index.

Some Pakistanis think Islamic stocks are always safer. That’s not correct. Islamic stocks can also fall. Always check fundamentals—profits, business model, and future plans.
practiceQuestions: What is a dividend?
What does KMI-30 represent?
Are Islamic stocks risk-free?

courses.title: Beginner Technical Analysis (Pakistan)
courses.description: Learn basic chart-reading methods used in Pakistani markets to understand price trends.

content.readingMaterial:
Technical analysis means studying price charts instead of company reports. Example: if OGDC price keeps making higher highs, that indicates an uptrend.

A candlestick chart shows open, high, low, and close price. Green candle usually means price went up, red means it went down. These charts are commonly used by Pakistani traders.

Support and resistance are important concepts. Support means a price where stock usually stops falling (buyers enter). Resistance means a price where stock usually stops rising (sellers enter). Example: Lucky Cement might repeatedly bounce around Rs.600 level.

Trend lines help you understand direction. If price is mostly rising, trend is positive. But trend can change anytime due to economic news.

But remember: technical analysis is not magic. Many Pakistanis rely only on charts and ignore company fundamentals. The best approach is mixing both—charts plus financial knowledge.
practiceQuestions: What does technical analysis study?
What is support in a chart?
Should technical analysis be used alone?

courses.title: Political & Economic Impact on PSX
courses.description: Learn how Pakistan’s economy, inflation, rupee rate, and government decisions affect stock movement.

content.readingMaterial:
Pakistan’s stock market is very sensitive to economic news. If inflation rises, cost of doing business becomes high, which reduces company profit. This may push stock prices down.

Rupee depreciation affects companies differently. Oil & gas importers may suffer because imports become expensive. But exporters like textile companies may benefit because they earn in foreign currency.

Interest rate changes by State Bank have huge effects. If interest rates rise, businesses borrow less. Banking sector might benefit from higher rates, but other sectors may slow down.

Political instability also impacts PSX. When elections are near, foreign investors become cautious. As a result, volumes may fall and volatility increases.

Many beginners ignore macro conditions and only look at stock price. Understanding Pakistan’s economy helps you invest smarter and avoid panic decisions.
practiceQuestions: How does inflation affect companies?
Which sector benefits from rupee depreciation?
Do elections affect PSX confidence?

quizzes.question: When rupee falls, which sector may gain?

courses.title: Long-Term Investing in Pakistan
courses.description: Learn how long-term investing works, how to build a portfolio, and avoid short-term panic.

content.readingMaterial:
Long-term investing means holding good companies for years, not days. Pakistan has many companies that have grown slowly over the last decade.

Compounding is powerful. If a company grows profits every year, your investment grows too. Dividends plus price increase can build wealth.

Instead of buying daily, invest monthly using a fixed amount. This method is called averaging. It reduces the effect of sudden price jumps.

Beginners in Pakistan often check stock price multiple times a day. That increases anxiety and panic decisions. Long-term investors check quarterly or monthly and study results.

Good long-term stocks usually have strong business models like banking, energy, fertilizers, or cement depending on demand and economic cycle. But research is always required.
practiceQuestions: What is long-term investing?
Why is averaging helpful?
How often should long-term investors check prices?
